data.name: Setting goals
data.description: Planning goals that are meaningful and measurable, and holding yourself accountable to them.

recommendations.markdown: Anyone who wants to accomplish things that take a lot of effort, multiple people, or a long time needs a method of creating goals and measuring them.

Do you have a list of goals, personal or professional, that you keep track of on a regular basis? For those goals, how easy is it to tell if you're making progress? Someone who excels at this skill has strategies for setting and tracking goals, and regularly checks on their goals and revises them as necessary.

A popular system for setting goals at any level has the acronym [SMART](https://www.atlassian.com/blog/productivity/how-to-write-smart-goals). Each letter in the acronym holds the goal-setter accountable to making good decisions about some aspect of the goal.

OKRs (Objectives and Key Results) are a system of setting and tracking goals that work for individuals and startups all the way to Google. The book [Measure What Matters](https://www.whatmatters.com/the-book) and its companion website help show the value of structuring goals in this way.

Goal setting should happen on a periodic basis. Depending on the size of the goals, they could be created and tracked on a weekly, monthly, quarterly, or yearly basis. Find a schedule that works for the kinds of goals that you're setting.
Consider the projects that you're working on right now. Take some time to think about whether you'll know when the project is complete. How do you measure it? When will you move onto the next thing?
